comment.author: 22694125@N02
comment._content: Congratulations! This is a wonderful shot! You are invited to post it to: artland

comment.author: 52008410@N00
comment._content: In some aspects - nothing has changed!

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I would suggest that it's a little earlier than 1900, especially if it is an albumen. Modern day Street View - www.google.co.uk/maps/preview#!q=Caius+College&data=!... I've made a geotag suggestion on my Commons tagging tool - see www.whatsthatpicture.com/flickr/commons/suggestions.php?n...

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] Thank you for showing us the beautiful street view of today on Google maps, as well as the geotag suggestion made on your Commons tagging tool (looks interesting, and I will certainly have a closer look!). Concerning the photo date, would you concider '1890s' more correct - or even earlier? I found an article on Wikipedia about the albumen print suggesting a peak of the albumen print method in the 1860-90s. (I also took the opportunity to correct some data for the photo, adding 'Gonville' to the name of the College building.) /Anna B.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Anna, that's a pleasure. Have you ever thought of setting up an account on www.historypin.com where you can overlay images onto Street View? Do take a look at my Commons tagging tool and see what you think. It is in early days and needs a few enhancements made, but with greater uptake I think could prove useful. For example you could set certain challenges based on sets, in the same way that Brooklyn did with geotagging some of their early collections (come to think of it, that was done so they could add them to Historypin!). The dating question is an interesting one. There are so few visual clues in the image that it is hard to tell, but my instinct is no later than 1890. I see we don't know who the photographer may have been, which is a shame.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content:
I've just been 'revisiting' this one, so to speak. It appears that there are a good few similar image in The Commons. This one from LoC is perhaps the most interesting as it has the same track marks and very similar carriages and style of dress. It is dated by them as ca 1890, though the description says 1890-1900
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/8370890374/]

Here are a couple of lovely images from Cornell that they date to 1870-1885 and they do have a slightly earlier feel to them
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/30515687@N05/3610778787/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/30515687@N05/3610694777/]

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Oh, and I've just found which on the source page at www.dakotaboo.com/postcards/topo-england/cambridgeshire.htm suggests a date of 1903. I suspect that's the date of the postcard rather than the image, but the bike does suggest a later date, and there are those distinctive track marks again. Maybe I was wrong as yours is a late 1890s / early 1900s image after all? Sorry!

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: But finally, check these from the Frith collection (dates are as they have given them) c1873 - www.francisfrith.com/cambridge,cambridgeshire/photos/caui... 1890 - www.francisfrith.com/cambridge,cambridgeshire/photos/caiu... 1890 - www.francisfrith.com/cambridge,cambridgeshire/photos/carr... (this is just a detail of the image above) 1921 - www.francisfrith.com/cambridge,cambridgeshire/photos/caiu... And on those tracks, this page says Cambridge had tram tracks for trolley-busses from 1880 to 1914.

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] James, you have made an impressive research, and I have really enjoyed looking at the images and following your reasoning! (Love that about the tram tracks - myself I started studying English horse carriages and found out about the Hansom cab, but that didn't help a lot in dating the image.) I think these different dates show how difficult it may be to date old images precisely. The dates suggested in your examples stretch from 1870 to 1903 for quite similar images. As you say, I think the photo from the Library of Congress is very close to ours (though tinted), and I will finally date our image c. 1890. Thanks again for your commitment in our Cambridge photo! It's also interesting to know that this was a very popular Cambridge motif for images in the late 1800s. I'm sorry for not having answered that yet, but yes, I know about Historypin and I really appreciate the site, but right now, we have no plans to expand our photo sharing to other sites than The Commons. Thanks anyway for the suggestion. :) /Anna
